project_questionnaire.project_title: Customer Churn Prediction - ML Project Template

questions_and_answers.question: What is Project Name?
questions_and_answers.answer: Customer Churn Prediction - ML Project Template

questions_and_answers.question: What is the business problem or technical challenge the project aims to solve and state the main goal of implementing the AI-based technology solution.
questions_and_answers.answer: Business Problem: High customer churn rate leading to revenue loss and increased customer acquisition costs. Technical Challenge: Identify at-risk customers before they leave using historical behavioral data. Main Goal: Implement an AI-based predictive model to identify customers with high churn probability (>70%) enabling proactive retention strategies. Expected Outcome: Reduce churn rate by 20% and increase customer lifetime value through early intervention.

Technical Stakeholders: Data Science Team, ML Engineering Team, Data Engineering Team, IT Operations
End Users: Customer Success Managers, Sales Representatives, Marketing Analysts
External: Customers (indirectly affected by retention campaigns)

questions_and_answers.question: Has this problem already been tackled or addressed in another facility before? (true = yes, false = no)
questions_and_answers.explanation: This is a template project designed to be the first standardized approach for churn prediction across the company

questions_and_answers.question: Has a similar implementation been done before in your organization? If so, provide details.
questions_and_answers.answer: No, this is the first standardized ML template for the organization. This project serves as the foundation and template for future ML implementations. The code structure in src/ (data_preprocessing.py, model_training.py, model_evaluation.py, prediction.py) is designed to be reusable across different ML projects.

questions_and_answers.question: When do you plan to launch this project?
questions_and_answers.answer: Template is production-ready immediately. Custom implementations typically require 1-3 months for full deployment including data integration, customization, and user training.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the first step in implementing this project?
questions_and_answers.answer: 1. Setup virtual environment and install dependencies (pip install -r requirements.txt), 2. Run main.py to verify template works with sample data, 3. Replace sample_data.csv with actual customer data, 4. Update config.py with correct column names and paths, 5. Customize features in data_preprocessing.py for specific business needs

questions_and_answers.question: What are the average resource requirements for this project?
questions_and_answers.answer: Technical Resources: 4GB RAM minimum (8GB recommended), 2-4 CPU cores, 1-5GB disk space. Human Resources: 1 Data Scientist (2-4 weeks), 1 ML Engineer (1-2 weeks), 1 Business Analyst (1 week). Cloud Resources: Basic instance (AWS t3.medium, Azure B2s) sufficient for up to 100K customers.

questions_and_answers.question: How long does it take to collect the necessary data?
questions_and_answers.answer: Historical data extraction: 1-2 days from existing systems (CRM, billing, support). Data integration and cleaning: 2-3 days. Template includes automatic sample data generation for immediate testing. Real data typically comes from customer database, billing system, and support tickets.

questions_and_answers.question: What are the specific requirements for data collection?
questions_and_answers.answer: Required columns: customer_id, age, tenure_months, monthly_charges, total_charges, contract_type, payment_method, support_calls, churn (target). Format: CSV with UTF-8 encoding. Minimum 500 customers, recommended 1000+. Historical data spanning 12+ months preferred. Data quality: <20% missing values per column.

questions_and_answers.question: What type of data will be used (structured, unstructured, etc.)?
questions_and_answers.explanation: Primarily structured tabular data (CSV format) with defined schema. Customer demographics, billing information, and support metrics are all structured numerical and categorical data.

questions_and_answers.question: What are the primary data sources?
answer: Customer Database: Demographics (age, location), account information (tenure, contract type)
Billing System: Monthly charges, total charges, payment history, payment methods
Support System: Number of support tickets, issue categories, resolution times
Usage Analytics: Product usage patterns, feature adoption, login frequency
CRM System: Customer interactions, satisfaction scores, engagement metrics

questions_and_answers.question: What is the approximate size of the dataset?
questions_and_answers.explanation: Template generates 1,000 sample customers (~100KB). Real implementations typically use 5K-50K customer records (~1-50MB). Includes numerical and categorical features as defined in config.py.

questions_and_answers.question: Does the data require annotation or labeling?
questions_and_answers.explanation: Supervised learning with historical churn labels already available. Target variable 'churn' indicates whether customer left (1) or stayed (0). No manual labeling required.

questions_and_answers.question: What type of model will be used?
questions_and_answers.explanation: Binary classification to predict churn (0=Stay, 1=Leave). Primary algorithm: Random Forest, alternative: Logistic Regression. Configurable in config.py MODEL_TYPE setting.

questions_and_answers.question: What are the model inputs/features?

answer.preprocessing: StandardScaler for numerical, OneHotEncoder for categorical

questions_and_answers.question: What are the model outputs?

answer.confidence: Prediction confidence based on probability distance from 0.5 threshold
answer.format: JSON for single predictions, CSV for batch predictions

questions_and_answers.question: What metrics will be used to evaluate model performance?

questions_and_answers.question: What is the expected model latency/response time?
questions_and_answers.explanation: Single customer prediction: <1 second. Batch predictions (1000 customers): <30 seconds. Training time: 30-60 seconds for template dataset.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the acceptable error frequency?
questions_and_answers.explanation: Current model achieves 85% accuracy (15% error rate). Business acceptable threshold: 80% accuracy (20% error rate). False positive rate: 17% is manageable for retention campaigns.

questions_and_answers.question: How will data drift be detected and handled?

answer.detection_methods: Feature distribution monitoring, new categorical values detection, performance degradation tracking
answer.monitoring_frequency: Monthly statistical tests on input features vs training data
answer.thresholds: Alert when feature distributions change >20% or accuracy drops >5%
answer.handling: Automatic model retraining trigger, feature engineering updates
answer.implementation: Can extend with MLflow or custom monitoring scripts

questions_and_answers.question: How often will the model be updated/retrained?
questions_and_answers.explanation: Recommended monthly retraining to capture seasonal patterns and evolving customer behavior. Can be triggered automatically when performance drops or data drift detected.

questions_and_answers.question: What metrics will trigger model updates?

answer.performance_triggers: Accuracy drops below 80%, precision below 75%, recall below 70%
answer.business_triggers: Actual churn rate differs >10% from predicted, retention campaign success rate <60%
answer.data_triggers: New feature distributions, missing value rates >25%, new categorical values
answer.time_triggers: Automatic monthly retraining regardless of performance
answer.manual_triggers: Business process changes, new product launches, major market events

questions_and_answers.question: How will model versions be managed?

answer.metadata_storage: Model type, training date, performance metrics stored with each version
answer.rollback_capability: Previous versions maintained for quick rollback if needed
answer.future_enhancement: Can integrate MLflow or DVC for advanced versioning and experiment tracking
